job_title: Field Education Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-got to work from home
-received a paycheck

cons:
-toxic environment 
-Walden is run more like a business than a school
-No work/life balance 
-Constantly short staffed/high turnover 
-Micromanagement 
-Unrealistic work load leading to stress and burnout 
-Restrictive program policies that ultimately hinder students 
-As a result, having to be constantly berated by students via phone & email who are upset by these policies and the inefficiency of the office even though it’s the fault of leadership and not you (you’re essentially being set up to fail) 
-No accountability held by leadership. More times than not, students are having horrible experiences while Walden collects more of their money and boasts about education for good.

cons: Poor vacation that doesn't accrue, raises below 1%, and no bonuses. The company chose not to match 401Ks during COVID despite being an online school. Quick rollouts of policies and programs keep you on your toes constantly. It's a very different feeling working for a for-profit university.

Being required to be very pushy on the phone and operate under a mentality of "enroll anyone and everyone."
Overall, I have deep philosophical differences with the for-profit higher education mjodel.

pros: Work from home, great boss, great pay, tuition discount, good people

pros:
As a Research  Intern,.  Walden provides the tools to work in a team as well as independently to improve your business  administration and healthcare Management skills. One is trained in  commutation skills, writing skills, presentation skills.  Walden help one to improve all your  independent skills and self -confidence to  work and solve problems in any business and healthcare organization industries. Walden helps one to be self-confident in using any type of quantitative and qualitative  analytical  tools. Walden helps one to analyze and think critically about business and healthcare management cases based on different organization policies. Then based on the above  one can suggest logical recommendation and adjustment.  Walden helps one to work  based on time management and attain the expected goals as a leader in any organization.
Walden helps to prepare you for leadership and management roles in any organization.
cons: At Walden, one has to be very patient, cool and determine to accomplish a perfect  job  and maintain good training performance scale or grade at the end of each assigned projects and work which can be very  strenuous. All work at  Walden  has a deadline which must be obeyed   each week according to  the organization mission, value, goal and culture.

review_title: It's Really all about the numbers!
pros:
With all jobs and with time the structure changes. At Walden the change was inevitable. The University in the past had awarded the enrollment advisors compensation for the number of enrollments they made since it technically is a sales position. There was no real strict script and no phone calls were recorded. You could be yourself more to engage potential students.
Good health and dental benefits & 401K match.
cons:
The company decided to change the verbiage the enrollments teams could use around after a company called Richardson did a training. This company has their own style of how to speak with potential clients. The job became very robotic and made it more difficult to focus on the important stuff like all the changes in the curriculums constantly. The managers would discuss your number of enrollments in private and push for higher numbers behind closed doors yet in the annual reviews nothing was mentioned regarding number of enrollments and the raises for the last 5 years of employment were cut by around 85%. You begin to feel like a slave for management and can't really understand the vague and somewhat fake evaluations. My particular manager was not very well liked by most the team and I ended up quitting due to her rudeness!!!
Not a lot of room for advancement at a satellite office.

pros: It's a job that's allowed me to grow as a technician
cons: It feels stagnant. I feel that I've reached a brick ceiling

review_title: Really hard on your mental health
job_title: Student Success Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
* It's in a nice area downtown.
* Tuition benefits.
* Some nice colleagues.
cons:
* Work flow is completely unmanageable. I frequently put in 10-12 hour days.
* The tools you are given to do your job don't work well.
* Consistent information is difficult to find. I felt constantly unsure that I was telling students the correct thing. If you truly like helping people, this really starts to wear on you because you could be unknowingly costing students money and time.
* I actually had a manager call me into her office to ask me how I'm doing and how I'm coping with the work load (she noticed that I had been working on some cases very late at night). I admitted that I was having a difficult time keeping up and meeting the service level agreement so I was needing to work from home late at night. She told me over and over again to please take care of mental health or I'd burn out. As I walked back to my desk, she messaged me (via Skype) saying, "You have one case out of SLA, it hasn't even been touched." It truly started to feel psychologically abusive.
* If you have to go on extended follow up after a call to research something (because you take your job seriously and truly want to help people), you'll get a terse message popping up on your screen that says, "Get back on the phone. You've been on follow up too long."

pros: The work from home once a week perk, employee tuition deduction and discount benefits. The Minneapolis, MN office is beautiful, clean,  convinient location in downtown. You feel appreciated to provide academic advising to students obtaining BS, MS or PhD degrees.
cons: The Minneapolis office is severely lacking diversity, having less then 5 individuals who are NOT White in a  200+ employee office is disgraceful, disheartning and concerning. The staff is unfriendly, not all of them, but majority unless you're someone they can relate to,. You feel a sense of white privilege rules only here and that's very unwelcoming to those who are from different race or a minority group, not a way to run a University that has 80% students from diverse backgrounds, most of them of which are African American students.

review_title: Seems Like Walden Has Improved Its Working Environment
pros: I worked at Walden for 3 and half years and was treated horribly, completely taken advantaged of, and fired for complaining about legitimate issues that I could have sued Walden for and won.   It's nice to finally read positive things about their work environment from others.
cons: When I was there, they had a series of unethical and abusive directors and managers.   I was made to cover for other people and work hundreds of overtime hours without pay.   I also had to work remotely on Christmas and New Years without pay because others called in sick or were allowed to take vacations after blackouts were enforced upon all others.

review_title: Know what you are getting into.
pros: The people are great and the pay is well for the industry compared to other for-profit online institutions. The benefits are goods, medical, dental, vision, 401K. You will be challanged in your role.
cons: Management leaves much to be desired.  While you can leave work at work, the work load is more then the 40 hours that one works in a week.  The work load is not evenly distributed you are either in a hurricane of activity or in the doldrums. If you want to grow within the company in this role it will require relocation to MN or MD.  Not too many opportunities for growth in Tempe.

review_title: This is the most unethical place I have ever worked for. I do not recommend.
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: For a call center, you get decent pay and benefits.
cons: As an enrollment advisor you are essentially a salesperson. I was told by trainers and management to pull out all the stops to keep a student - including encouraging them to take out loans and using personal stories they may share with me to my advantage. For example if a potential student says they are interested in Walden because they want to set an example for their daughter about the importance of education, if that same person finds they cannot afford the program I should guilt them into staying. The programs are not worth the money (40k+ for discussion posts), so it feels horrible encouraging people to take on debt for that. The environment is completely run on micromanagment. The tone of your voice, the number of dials you make, the length of your calls, and the calls themselves are heavily monitored so that you do not have an ounce of truth in your calls.

pros: Flexibility and independence and working with students.
cons: I have never seen a raise in pay for faculty in  the 10 years I taught at Walden although I kept waiting to see at least one pay increase. Advice: At least give your faculty a pay increase to coincide with the standard of living and what a good job faculty do at your University.  It is really disheartening how low Walden pays for teaching courses especially with a much work that is expected from them. Why have faculty evaluations if you never provide a pay increase in my question.

pros: The reasons for working at the Minneapolis office of Walden University are limited.  Senior management has changed.  The best reason to work for Walden as a whole is tuition reimbursement if taking Walden courses.  Although not as much, tuition reimbursement for attending any college or university approved by the Higher Learning Commission if not Walden is reasonable.
cons:
E-mails to senior management are unanswered.   The chain of command is strictly adhered to so if a problem occurs and a link in the chain is out, the problem has to wait.  

Sad faces - no supervisory support

pros: Great benefits, many of them company paid; great coworkers; ample free parking; good working environment depending on which department you're in
cons: Management in multiple departments needs training to understand how to manage people; some departments are treated unfairly overall; change is VERY slooooow in terms of policies, procedures, tech upgrades, and remote work options (again, varied by department)

pros: Supportive and knowledgeable colleagues, great health and wellness benefits, opportunities to work on projects of interest, work from home options
cons: Unsupportive and gaslighting management who treat staff as singles without family or friends, unrealistic workload expectations (>700 students per advisor, adding 40+ new students every Term Start), little room for advancement; negative and condescending attitudes from management

pros: Great benefits including an occasional work from home day. Wonderful social change mission. Convenient office location.
cons:
Management over leadership, vast amount of HIGHLY unqualified students enrolled, lack of diversity in the work place from a school whose student body is largely made up of racial and ethnic minorities. 

Support for work staff is non-existent. Department "standards" are thrown out the window to accommodate unqualified students who complain. Remote "leadership" is only concerned with numbers and does not value quality of the degree programs provided. 

1% raises are the norm and there is no opportunity for growth.

review_title: Great experience for a phone job
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Positive office morale/  No individual pressure to meet numbers / Thorough new hire training / Good benefits / The legitimacy of the school; sales itself to prospects / Don't have to swindle prospects into a degree / Autonomy while working; management isn't constantly  looking over your shoulder
cons: Very few options for advancement / 100% phone job -- gets monotonous quick

review_title: Don't believe a word they say in the interview
pros: flexible hours, good benefits - that is it
cons:
management speaks of how you are there to help people, yet all they care about is numbers
they know from day 1 who will move up in the company and who won't.. they have very strict rules regarding promotions however those are only in place for people they don't favor.  they present new positions to people and then go back and say it wasn't properly approved, please wait patiently

management harps that it is a numbers game and a sales job, which is a title violation of title iv.  there is no compensation for your sales due to the school receiving financial aid

review_title: Very progressive and innovative in my time there.
pros: The organization continues to grow and evolve.  Top sales management did a great job of communicating with the team.  70% tuition discount.
cons: Ok if you are good with sitting in a cube all day.  They offer distance education which is often considered  a lower quality of education as compared to traditional universities with a ground campus.  Admission requirements for students are low but better than some other online for profit schools.  Student loans (as with any university) contributes to next bubble, the education bubble (just as we had a tech bubble and a housing bubble).

review_title: Needs better distribution of workload, great pay and co-workers.
pros: Great pay, great co-workers, great benefits. It's gratifying to help students complete their degrees and meet their goals.
cons: The work load is either feast or famine. When it's busy, such as, students calling in/emailing, the powers that be load us up with work and deadlines that make me want to pull my hair out. And when it's quiet, it's quiet.

pros:
Decent benefits and work hours.
conveniently located in downtown Minneapolis.
cons:
Huge disparity in work flow. Make sure that you dont get stuck advising undergrads; these students are accepted into the program no matter what, so you will be dealing with a lot of idiots.  Promotion is based solely on favoritism rather than ability. 
Call center environment.  
Management is incapable simply they have reached their personal level of incompetence.
Lack of diversity.  When I left the organization there were only 3 other people of color in the Minneapolis office.

review_title: Coming from 7 yrs as a self employed independent contractor I feel like a caged lion, with underused skills.
job_title: Enollment Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Health benefits, set work hours, overtime available, typical holidays (no retail hours), no hard labor, education discount, 401k if you participate, nice people, location if you live in West LA or nearby, not rocket science
cons: Not physical enough you will get fat if not careful, excessive outbound calls to people who are not always pleased, work time conflicts with our students work schedule, not alot of room for advancement in the same department, government regulation is pending, management are not trained leaders

review_title: A shift in priorities will seal success for the future
job_title: Student Support Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Globally aware company, Flexible work/life balance for most, great pay and benefits depending on what you're doing. Very community centered and well known in volunteer efforts and partnerships.
cons: Pay and raises aren't reflective or talent. There are too many with talent who are getting the short end of the stick compared to others with less education, less time on the job and less accolades.

job_title: Student Support in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Walden University tries to streamline all processes so that students don't feel like we are fumbling behind the phones. When we place students on hold, we scramble looking for answers that aren't readily available.  But we get the answer and send the student off.
cons: Lack of leadership.  Lack of confidence in the atmosphere. Management doesn't open up to new creative ideas that can make the customer service team run smoothly.

review_title: Great company for jump starting your career.
pros: This company gives excellent pay without requiring much experience. It's in a great downtown location; very upscale environment. Routinely promotes good employee morale through company sponsored events. Also provides you with intensive training and follow up training. There is a lot of promotion from within.
cons: It can be extremely challenging for someone who is not a good fit for a particular position; specifically, something in sales.

review_title: Good School - Not so Good Place of Employment
pros: Discounts available on Master's and Doctoral & PhD level programs are unbeatable. Experience with the online learning format is also valuable.
cons: Monotonous work. Not much room for growth or promotion. Unfair and discriminatory promoting and pay scale. Vindictive managers. Childish "In" & "Out" crowds even among managers leads to obvious disparities in treatment for small and large issues.

pros: DBA program manager is accessible and responsive.  I work as many hours as I like, and I can teach courses as well as mentor students working on research studies. Other instructors I have met are qualified and supportive.
cons: Doctoral study requirements are too prescriptive, and the MyDr process is onerous.  Committee chairs are required to spend too much time managing the process and editing students' work.  When I consider all the time required mentoring students and teaching courses, I make less than minimum wage.

pros: Co-workers and benefits are the only reason to be here
cons: Utterly unrealistic workload. Management has no concern for how quickly they are burning out employees

review_title: Poor focus, incompetent executives, too many managers not enough focus on student learning
pros: Flexible schedule to a degree.
cons: Favoritism, lack of focus on scholarship (indeed, to some managers, scholarship is a hobby that interferes with "the business" of getting and retaining students, almost at any cost), hostile work environment, command and control structure. Bunus structure favors upper management and is not at all clear as to criteria for earning a bonus. Pay rate is entirely arbitrary. In spite of the company focus on "social change," the culture of the university is entirely focused on an unnecessary bureaucracy. Courses are not updated (some in more than a decade) or revised in a reasonable manner, and faculty have very little say in the content of the courses they teach.

pros: Good co-workers, good medical and other benefits
cons: Raises are joke.  Very subjective and always less than 3 percent. Teams are often short staffed and it takes months to replace a vacancy on the team. Work load increases every semester.  The school is using very outdated technology.  Very limited opportunities for advancement

review_title: Highly recommend you don't take a job working for Walden in their Admissions Department
pros: The pay is above average.
cons: They expect you to work overtime for free by classifying everyone except for Enrollment as "non-exempt".  Admissions Specialists, depending on the college you work for, can easily put in 10 or more hours of overtime for each of two weeks before every start date. The managers are inconsistent  with following policies and rarely know what the policies are.  Managers are not qualified...mine was 26 years old and had no previous management experience at all.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great pay and they allow for overtime on occasion. The teams are close and if you have a good enrollment manager the job is pretty easy. Also, the computer system is fast so that is a definite plus and makes your job a lot easier. Someone is always willing to help you.  If you do work hard there is definitely room for growth.
cons: The one issue I came accross, not personally, but on some other teams there was a lot of micro-managing which usually caused rift on teams and poor performance.

pros: Flexible schedule, ability to work with students from around the globe, exposure to and opportunity to collaborate with those students on pressing contemporary issues.
cons: Some students have unrealistic expectations about what it takes to pursue a doctoral degree. They think the process should be quick and approval of their research should happen after a specific number of reviews rather than meeting expectations of scholarly research. A modest number of students lack adequate preparation for graduate level thinking and writing requirements. This makes it very challenging to guide those students to success.

review_title: Some good, some bad, some VERY bad
pros: Travel to different areas if you advised for programs with residency requirements.
cons: Salary increases non existant, good workers reprimanded for one mistake while bad workers get free passes on mistakes, no viable promotion path unless someone quits.

review_title: Contributing faculty are small cogs in a big machine.
pros: Flexibility, relationships with students, varied opportunities to teach courses and mentor students. Some support from other parts of the institution.
cons: Impersonal. No one knows you and you know no one unless you attend the in person meetings which are invite only unless you want to pay to fly to Baltimore or Florida.

pros: Nice desk job . Sometimes company treats staff to bagels or pizza. Co workers are very helpful. Walden is an equal opportunity employer. Managing is very nice.
cons: Bad company culture. Employees talk very poorly of the students that they are trying to help. A lot of things don’t get done in a timely manner in the financial aid department. Students are more angry than not . We could do a lot more to help students.

pros: Healthy work environment, good benefits, flexibility, work from home, family-friendly, supports innovation, fairly flat org structure
cons: Bureaucracy that comes with being part of the Laureate Network, student retention is a big issue due to open access philosophy, Laureate doesn't always understand needs of Walden

pros:
Very reasonable pay and benefits, $22/hr and benefits start quickly.
Good office setting, friendly people
Business done over the phone and computer - if you don't have a very strong phone presence, do not apply.
Lots of team building and morale boosting
cons:
Unclear expectations for new hires - you get general training on how to do your job, but a lot of critical processes aren't discussed and you're expected to learn as it's happening.
18th century cubicles - we need better chairs, standing desks and wireless headsets.

pros: There are some great people here who care about doing a good job. They have good ideas and want to make a good student experience.
cons: The staff is given conflicting direction constantly and ridiculous timelines. The organization is so matrixed that no one knows what anyone else is doing and poor decisions result.

pros: Easy work for experienced academics. Classes have no hands on so it's all slide ware.
cons: Classes are now huge to cut costs. Mine are twice as large.  Classes are many years out of date and broken ones are not fixed. Senior management is protecting their bonuses by ripping off students and faculty.  Faculty has no say in academic matters of substance.

review_title: Advisors Care about Students Upper Management Does Not
job_title: Student Success Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Coworkers make it manageable some days
cons: Unrealistic Expectations and micromanaging by all levels of management

pros: The benefits are pretty good, the location is great...in a growing area of Baltimore City. They offer a discount on tuition. if you stay with the company long enough, there are plenty of opportunities for advancement.
cons: Office politics can sometimes get in the way of career progress...restrictions that apply to you may not apply to others.

review_title: Best Place I have Ever Worked
job_title: Student Success Advisor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Walden University in Tempe AZ is the best place I have worked in my career. My manager is good and understanding. The director is a nice guy and very approachable. The staff is friendly, and all get along. Leadership doesn’t have unreasonable expectations. It’s a really good environment and I am happy to be here.
cons: There is limited opportunity for advancement.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Hours are typically 8-5 with one day a week working 11-8pm. 
Benefits are excellent, vision, dental, healthcare, even life insurance.
cons: can feel like cold-calling. you do almost the same thing every day. But they have a lot of events and fun things to do to help. Very little room to move up in some locations.

pros: One day a week WFH opportunity
cons: Probably the worst experience I've had in my career to this day. I worked with a team of some of the most uptight and stuck up people I have ever met and just an angry and negative supervisor who seemed to hate the world around her. Everything started out fine, however, half way through my time there, I started to get singled out by my team members and ultimately, by my supervisor for various reasons. Every time I asked for help, it felt like I was asking for the world from everyone since everyone was always busy, so it was difficult to get any additional training that was needed. And then, I would also get scolded for not asking for help. So it was always a lose-lose for me. You are also constantly micromanaged. My supervisor claimed that she did not micromanage even though she said that she "knows what is going on at all times" and felt that she had to talk to me once because she said I was gone from my computer for a long period of time when I was WFH. So after a while, my supervisor made it very clear that she did not want me there anymore, as she hinted that I should think about whether that job was for me or not. There was no hesitation on my end, as I had already realized that prior to the conversation and left as soon as I could. I left my previous job to come here because I had wanted to pursue a career in the education field and thought this would have been a way to get my foot in the door but in this case, the grass was not greener on the other side. I've decided to pursue a different career path and am happier now for it. This experience has definitely made me a better person and I am thankful for that, but I would never recommend anyone taking a chance here. You will not get paid well and you will not advance quickly in your career here.  The benefits also suck. Pursuing your education here is also a joke. I heard of so many instances of students wanting to sue the school for various reasons. You're better off getting your degree at Walmart.

review_title: Pros and Cons like any other place
pros: Fair and competitive pay, ability to work remotely (depending on department), ever growing, room for advancement
cons: Lots of office politics (that don't always create the best work environments. Competitive company where the student and/or employee is not always considered.

pros: A great company to work for. Always on the edge of innovation. A fast paced, and well maintained work environment .
cons: At times, it was difficult to move to other roles in the company. I tried on several different occasions to coordinate my migration to a different department to assist, and the scheduling conflicts outweighed the projects that I was working on.

review_title: Great to help students and receive their appreciation, depressing to know how hard we are worked.
pros: Very rewarding to hear a student achieve milestones in his or her studies, life, or goals.
cons: It is an online university, but we can't work from home even a day or two per month?

pros: There are none....it is a toxic culture that cookie cutters everything and micro manages in an incompetent and hostile manner
cons:
Just about everything.  Faculty have no academic freedom and the requirements are insipid
and geared for mass production of low level academic students.  Student can have outside agencies write their dissertations for them under the guise of polishing the dissertation.

pros: Laureate is a solid company to work for, for the most part.   There are big changes now, but overall, the organization has room for growth and makes reasonable attempts to provide employee incentives and rewards for superior productivity.
cons: Regular micro managing, favorites, and department changes.

review_title: Walden Library is a great place to work!
pros: Fantastic management, fantastic leadership, lot of freedom to manage your own work, be creative, try things. All staff work remotely.
cons: Corporate bottom line is about enrollment numbers, not scholarship.

pros: A very good school- as far as the industry goes... I never felt that prospective students were cheated by a non-marketable degree.  Solid benefits.
cons: Expectations exceeded reality.  Micro-managed to the point of being intolerable. I lost all faith in the ability of management to see the ramifications of their actions.

review_title: Employees are not valued except as a means to an end.
job_title: Nurse Field Education Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The only good reason to work there is for the benefits and the occasional work from home day.
cons: There is no work life balance. Leadership is oblivious to the volume of work and the amount of time it takes to accomplish tasks. They claim to care about students but really only care about the bottom line. Salary is low for this profession. Highly stressful.

pros: Walden does have a good concept but due to lack of leadership, it is left behind other universities
cons: Managers are not managing fairly. Trainers onboard were attempting to re-train advisors to be 'scripting.' Everyone is to fit in the same box-no creativity.

review_title: The job is ok. It has its good things and its bad...
pros: Full benefits,  paid holidays off, occasionally working from home
cons: Making outbound calls all day long....every department runs differently so you get different answers to the same questions.

review_title: Corporate job - you feel nothing but a number
pros: benefits and salary are great, with opportunity to take classes on a side for self-development.
cons: segregated workplace with poor management and communication in between departments. opinions and suggestions are not welcome.

review_title: Run, Don't Walk Away If Offered a Job
pros: The opportunity to work with students from all over the country, to improve your PC skills and to help students with their problems and questions.
cons: Toxic office politics of back stabbing and tattling you off to co workers and supervisors without providing all of the information.  Very cliquish.

job_title: Assistant Field Education Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: This job is stable, consistent, and gives you both the opportunity to talk with people and plug in. It's an awesome first job after college!
cons: It's a cube job so inevitably you go a little stir crazy. Walden is still pretty new and growing really fast so change happens CONSTANTLY.

pros:
Great support
Fair pay
Motivated students
Lots of grading resources
cons: As an adjunct, most courses go to "core" faculty, which can make for some lean paychecks.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: -Committed to social change (ostensibly)
cons: -Incapable took over the company.  Note the word "company" - it's about business and profits, not students.

pros: There is room for advancement and professional development for staff who push themselves.
cons: Company investment in itself and employees is unclear. There are good benefits, but also the sense that the budgets of service-providing teams stagnate or get cut before marketing budgets.

review_title: Master Student.  Nonprofit Mgmt and Leadership
pros: I have plenty of years working with people and numbers, specifically accounting in large corporate environments.  Now am looking for fewer hours while I finish my master's degree
cons: It is understandable, but sometimes people can be grouchy.

job_title: Contributing Faculty in Minn City, MN
pros: Very flexible, great training, focused on social change and provides numerous opportunities for faculty.
cons: the pay is not commensurate with the work

review_title: Faculty Retention is part of Walden's best attributes
pros: Have opportunity to mentor doctoral students and guide them towards earning their degrees
cons: Sometimes the on-line (asynchronous) communications  can pose a problem

review_title: It's a good place to work, more sales oriented than I would want
pros: Flexibility with scheduling and ways to be active in career development
cons: More sales oriented, but they are trying to do better

review_title: Advising department needs to be investigated.
pros: Great health insurance.  Convenient location. fitness club near by.
cons: Leadership is not great.  Command and Control all the way.  Employees are treated like a commodity rather an asset.  No upward mobility, unless you are favored by the Director.  Being favored is not relevant to performance, rather, your tolerance to submit 100%.

pros: I love my manager and my team!
cons: Low raises and working a late night is awful.

pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Disconnect between different depts, hard to work in sales when important changes are not communicated.   A couple of the supervisors are very unfair, unprofessional, rude and wanted to micromanage every minute of their team's time and many of the rest just incompetent.  And opportunities for advancement are not fairly given but already preselected by management.

pros: Good Pay and opportunity sometimes to go to faculty meetings
cons: Heavy handed administration  who say one thing but do another

pros: The location is great the leadership team is wonderful and the program offering are the best in the industry.
cons: Long work hours and you need to know a ton of information.

pros: There are some great people there.
cons: It's hard to see how people stay. If they aren't laid off, the culture really takes a toll. Awful morale.

job_title: Contributing Faculty Part Time in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Online flexibility, outstanding courses to teach, supportive program managers.
cons: There are no negative aspects of this employer based on my experiences.

pros:
Incredible staff
Opportunity to collaborate
Effective online working environment
cons: Few opportunities for growth and creativity

pros: Work remote and some good coworkers
cons: Lack of leadership, poor communication, terrible technology infrastructure

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Their commitment to social change, pay, environment, the people I worked with and for
cons: They do not always communication important information in a timely manner

pros: I love teaching at Walden University. It offers a wealth of resources for students and faculty.
cons: There are really no cons while working at Walden University.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Walden University is a great place is worked.  The staff was amazing.
cons: I do not have any cons

review_title: Program coordinator, core faculty, and content expert.
job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Bethesda, MD
pros: innovated, quality important, student centered
cons: Very tightly structured, failure to share information with many employers

pros: Great benefits, 401k matching each year, education discount.
cons: horrible pay and annual raises, no work-life balance, instability, horrible management.

job_title: Community Development Manager in Tempe, AZ
pros: Work from home opportunities.
cons:
No room for advancement. 
Poor communication. 
If you luck out and get a bad manager, you're stuck with them forever.

pros: Great benefits and good pay
cons: The constant change leaves one feeling unstable at times

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Minneapolis, MN
pros: flexible schedule, social justice, colleagues, staff, students
cons: remote, little advancement, heavy work load, students who complain, meetings

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Remote, OR
pros: Flexible schedule, ability to set own hours
cons: Lower pay than market average

review_title: dull, boring and not going anywhere
pros: 9-5, decent pay for what you are required to do, no responsibilities after work
cons: generally poor management, unfair promotion practices, not room for growth, little challenge

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Job security and good culture
cons: Late night shifts during the winter

pros: very flexible, technology based, accredited university
cons: none, I have nothing but good things to say about Walden

pros: Very supportive administration! Very flexible schedule! Collegiate atmosphere.
cons: No cons to report at this time

pros: Good company to get business and administrative experience with.
cons: Very limited internal advancement opportunities.

pros: Experience,pay and benefit of cotinuing or furthering your education.
cons: None atall and stability. Thats all.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Columbia, MD
pros: flexible, collaborative, team to work with
cons: no growth opportunity, promotions, or salary raise

job_title: Admissions Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Goods team work, dressy casual dress, and food training
cons: Too corporate, micro management, mammary favorites

pros: high pay and benefits with some really great people
cons: poor communication, silos, unrealistic expectations

pros: Flexible, travel, set own schedule, choose classes
cons: cookbook approach to teaching, lack of community

job_title: Core Faculty in South Pittsburg, TN
pros: Love working from home. No commute
cons: Leadership is not easy to approach

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great Benefits, Good Pay, Room to grow
cons: No longer located in Los Angeles

pros: Benefits, salary, support, the people
cons: Lack of communication from upper management

pros: Flexible, management, culture, students, experience
cons: Part time, low pay, none

pros: The money they and and the hours
cons: Too busy all the time

pros: The atmosphere between colleagues was great.
cons: No true connections between departments

job_title: Student Success Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Co-workers, salary, benefits, work from home during COVID
cons: Leadership is out of control, power hungry, does not have any regard for employees

pros:
Good benefits
Based in convenient central location
cons:
Home office is in Maryland
Be ready to be micromanaged
Cold, corporate culture
